comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: Hi Greg, the barge in this photograph was the Lord Mayors barge. "The protection of the river was demonstrated each year on Barge Day when the Mayor, in his capacity as President of the Court of Admiralty, inspected riverside staithes etc..This system survived until 1974 when the office of Alderman was abolished." Read more on Newcsatle City Council Website by following the link below www.newcastle.gov.uk/core.nsf/a/lmhistory?opendocument

comment.author: 22081583@N06
comment._content: The diary of Ralph Jackson describes the scene on the Tyne on 27 May 1756 when he followed the Great Barge up the river. There was also a smaller barge which carried the River Jury, do you know what their role was? The procession appears to have been part of the Beating the Bounds as they walked to a boundary stone a mile inland of Newburn. Beating the Bounds was carried out on Ascension Day.

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: The River Court was granted to the Corporation of Newcastle and dealt with matters relating to the conservancy of the River Tyne and included such matters as building staithes, which blocked the River, the dumping of ballast etc. The court was held before the mayor of the town and other officials and some matters were held before jurors of the River Court who were sworn in on a yearly basis.
